stream_context.summary: Kaze and guest developer Sauraen spend the session profiling and live-editing the new F3DEX3 microcode, trying to understand why it slows Return to Yoshi’s Island instead of accelerating it. After extensive A/B tests, new performance counters, and code edits, they narrow the mystery to an unexplained 8-9 ms of extra RSP time. The technical deep-dive happens while Kaze polishes “Calamari Desert,” a Mario Kart inspired retro course.

development_findings.summary: F3DEX3 was designed to add advanced graphics and cut RDP time, but in RTYI it raises RSP time, negating gains. Baseline tests show F3DEX2 ≈ 21.7 ms, old EX3 ≈ 25.5 ms, new EX3 ≈ 27 ms on RSP.
development_findings.quote: Increase features… and reduce RDP time… The cost is that our SP time goes up.

development_findings.summary: Kaze’s levels are almost entirely vertex-coloured; only moving actors use up to seven directional lights and no point lights to maintain emulator compatibility.
development_findings.quote: No, absolutely not, because I want to make sure it runs fine on emulators.

development_findings.summary: Lighting was disabled in microcode (one line commented) and saved just ~2 ms, proving lighting isn’t the main bottleneck; majority of vertices (≈ 4 300 of 6 600) are unlit.
Occlusion-plane math is executed for every vertex even though RTYI doesn’t use the feature; Sauraen plans to remove or gate this code to test impact.
Custom counters added show ~10 ms on vertex processing and ~8 ms on triangle setup, yet total RSP task is ~27 ms. About 8-9 ms remain unaccounted, implying another hidden cost or wait state.
development_findings.quote: That should make 18 ms, but we’re seeing 27 ms. Something else is taking a ton of time.

development_findings.summary: Command counter reveals ~8 000 display-list commands for the test scene—comparable to OOT—so command flood is ruled out.
Sauraen considers a hybrid ‘F3DEX 2.5’ (EX3 features but EX2 vertex path) tailored to RTYI’s limited lighting needs.
development_findings.quote: I may need to make F3DEX 2.5 for Kaze… a mish-mash to suit your needs.

context_findings.summary: Kaze prioritises fast iteration: still uses Project64 1.6 and Everdrive X5 despite security warnings, because other tools are slower.
context_findings.quote: I have no reason to get Parallel… Project64 is just so convenient to use.

context_findings.summary: Design view: gameplay should stay Mario-centric; he rejects a drivable kart in the retro level to avoid gimmicks.
context_findings.quote: We want the fun to be for Mario’s movement and not just random things like that.

context_findings.summary: He avoids point lights and some new EX3 options to keep the hack performant on real N64 and emulators.
Acknowledges widespread resale of ROM-hack repro carts; uneasy but accepts it as part of the scene.
context_findings.quote: It was bizarre seeing Missing Link sold for $50… none of that money is going to Nintendo or us.

context_findings.summary: Streaming set-up is fragile (OBS crashes if he touches settings), confirming limited bandwidth for polish during dev streams.

zeina.summary: Zeina briefly appears in chat and subscribes; no development details this stream.

key_stories.title: The Missing Milliseconds
key_stories.summary: Kaze and Sauraen expected EX3 to speed RTYI up by 5–15 %, but real hardware tests show it slower than EX2. They embark on a live coding session to uncover why.
key_stories.challenge: EX3’s RSP time is ~27 ms vs EX2’s 21 ms, eliminating the anticipated performance win.
key_stories.process: They profile old/new EX3, strip out lighting, add custom cycle counters, and compare vertex/triangle timings, discovering an unexplained 8–9 ms gap.
key_stories.outcome: Root cause still unknown; Sauraen will create deeper profiling tools and may craft a hybrid EX 2.5 microcode.
key_stories.key_quote: This should be 18 ms, but it’s 27 ms—something else is going on.

key_stories.title: Lighting vs. Compatibility
key_stories.summary: RTYI deliberately forgoes point lights to guarantee emulator parity, pushing visual flair into vertex colours instead.
key_stories.challenge: Advanced EX3 lighting features risk inconsistent performance across emulators.
key_stories.process: Kaze limits scenes to vertex colours and up to seven directional lights computed on CPU.
key_stories.outcome: Simpler lighting guides microcode decisions and may justify a leaner EX 2.5.
key_stories.key_quote: I stick to just directional lights because I want to make sure it runs fine on emulators.

open_questions.context: Vertex (~10 ms) + triangle (~8 ms) time doesn’t explain the 27 ms total; extra 8–9 ms remain unidentified.
questions: What exact microcode routines execute during the missing 8–9 ms?
Could overlay swaps or occlusion-plane code be stalling SP?
Does memory bandwidth or DMA contention throttle EX3 uniquely in RTYI?

open_questions.context: Sauraen floated ‘F3DEX 2.5’ mixing EX2 vertex path with EX3 features.
questions: What would the roadmap and effort be for a custom EX 2.5?
Which EX3 features (occlusion plane, cell shading) are non-negotiable for RTYI?
How will testing and maintenance be handled post-release?

open_questions.context: RTYI currently pays compute cost for an occlusion feature it doesn’t use.
questions: Will you disable or repurpose occlusion planes in final build?
Could conditional compilation or runtime flags eliminate unused code?
Is there a future design reason to keep occlusion planes despite current cost?

open_questions.context: Kaze still swaps SD cards manually; Sauraen suggests USB-based SummerCart64.
questions: Will Kaze adopt SummerCart64 to speed iteration?
What blockers prevent switching tools (driver issues, cost)?
